Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: SSDIM: Superimposed Simulations: Fast Generation of Synthetic Data of Interdependent Critical Infrastructures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
To guide the design, construction, operation and improved understanding of modern interdependent critical infrastructure (ICI) systems, decision-makers require data that capture the interactions among them their actors (i.e., citizens, firms, developers, and governments). Detailed computer simulations are essential to generating such data, particularly when physical implementations of ICI designs do not yet exist. However, generation of data derived from simulations is time consuming due to the complexity of the systems that must be modeled and the large number of computational experiments that are required. To address this challenge new computer algorithms exploiting modern high performance computing technologies will be developed. In this EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project, algorithms will be applied to create data sets for test cases including the interaction of water, energy, transportation infrastructures and people in the city of Atlanta. The new algorithms will provide insights into how to evaluate threats and opportunities within and across ICIs, to analyze strengths and weaknesses, and to design solutions, products, and services that meet societal needs and goals.

Current computational methods to assess options, various technology combinations, and human interactions within ICIs are time-consuming and computationally intensive. A new approach, termed superimposed simulations, will be developed to rapidly create synthetic data that captures the interdependencies and dynamics of critical infrastructures and people. By exploiting similarities among the many simulation runs in conjunction with parallel computing techniques, the new algorithms aim to accelerate simulations involving multiple interacting and interdependent critical infrastructure systems and human actors by one or two orders of magnitude. These newly developed algorithms will allow the quick generation of large data sets that can be used to determine the effects of ICI combinations, human behaviors, and policy tools on energy, water, carbon emissions, and human health.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The sustainable growth of cities is imperative as more and more of the world’s population resides in urban regions. It is widely recognized that effective management of growth requires a holistic approach that considers the interactions among urban infrastructures rather than simply managing each in isolation. Computer simulations are an essential tool to understand the ramifications of new technologies as they become deployed in modern cities. However, the computation time to complete simulations for coupled urban infrastructures is excessively long, negatively impacting the quality of the studies that can be undertaking.

This project explored the development of new technologies to reduce the time required to create and execute simulations of coupled urban infrastructures. Specifically, a technique called granular cloning was developed and evaluated that exploits the fact the simulation studies typically require many executions of a simulation model, and there is often much common computation among the different runs. These common computations need only performed once, and their results shared among the different runs. The granular cloning approach was developed and implemented. It demonstrated up to an order of magnitude speed up in completing simulation of coupled transportation and land use simulation models.

Other research in the project focused on the accelerating the development of coupled land use and transportation simulation models through the definition of a common data model. Further, research examining techniques to reduce the amount of energy consumed by coupled simulation models, and a middleware approach termed the Green Runtime Infrastructure was developed to create energy efficient computational services to couple simulations. This work suggests that new lines of research in energy efficient middleware for distributed simulations can provide significant benefit, and area not extensively studied in the modeling and simulation research community.

Project results were incorporated into interdisciplinary undergraduate and graduate courses offered at Georgia Tech. In addition, the project provided partial support for three doctoral students at Georgia Tech, with two completing their degree during the duration of the project.
